DOC.TEXT: Investors took the Panama crisis in stride with only a few brief blips registering on financial markets around the world. The dollar, oil and many stocks moved higher Wednesday on the news of the surprise U.S. military action, but prices later receded amid the usual concerns about interest rates and the economy. President Bush ordered troops into Panama on Tuesday night following several days of tension.

Citibank closed its branches in Panama City, soap-making at the Colgate-Palmolive factory halted and Borden shut an ice cream plant following the U.S. military action in Panama. The Panama Canal was also closed Wednesday, but shippers remained calm, although a prolonged shutdown could delay exports of South American fruit, raise some prices in the United States and force importers to find alternate routes.

The U.S. economy grew at a faster rate in the third quarter than previously estimated, the government said, but analysts say it is fast running out of steam and some suggest it is flirting with a recession. The Commerce Department said Wednesday the gross national product grew at an annual rate of 3 percent in the July-September period, up from a 2.5 percent rate reported in October and the subsequent revision to 2.7 percent last month.

European food concern TLC Beatrice International Inc.'s decision to scrap a public stock offering to raise up to $194 million reflects a general weakness in the market for new issues, analysts said. The move also postponed what would have been two firsts: the first former Beatrice Cos. spinoff to go public since a $6 billion takeover of the conglomerate in 1986 and the first black-owned company to be listed on the New York Stock Exchange. TLC Beatrice on Tuesday canceled the offering of 18.5 million shares of stock priced from $9 to $10.50 a share.

Billionaire Donald Trump reportedly is among bidders weighing a possible purchase of Bloomingdale's but the department store chain's troubled owner, Campeau Corp., declined to confirm Trump's interest. Campeau spokeswoman Carol Sanger said Wednesday the company intends to maintain silence for the duration of the sale process. The identity of the bidders will not be disclosed and all negotiations are confidential. Meanwhile Wednesday, two clothing makers joined merchandise credit firms in suspending business with Campeau's Federated and Allied department stores as a result of Campeau's financial situation.

A proposal by the European Economic Community to overhaul agricultural trade will clear the way for final negotiations with the EEC in 1990, the Bush administration said. ``This is the last of the major proposals to be submitted and now will permit the final negotiations on agriculture to get under way early next year,'' U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills and Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said Wednesday. However, they said, the United States cannot accept an EEC proposal to ``rebalance'' import protection, Mrs. Hills and Yeutter said.

American Airlines Chairman Robert L. Crandall said his deal to buy foreign routes and other assets of Eastern Airlines should be approved by government regulators ``in the national interest.'' Failure to allow the deal would invite greater control of international air travel by foreign carriers, Crandall said Wednesday of the $471 million purchase announced Tuesday. The complex deal with Eastern parent Texas Air Corp. gives American control of Eastern's prized Latin American routes and would greatly enhance American's presence in foreign markets.

State officials took action to oust the head of Florida's largest savings and loan, claiming he used $45 million in depositors' money to bankroll an art collection and extravagant lifestyle. David L. Paul, chairman and chief executive officer of CenTrust Bank of Miami, has 21 days to resign or contest a complaint filed Wednesday by Comptroller Gerald Lewis. A statement released by CenTrust said Paul would ``vigorously oppose'' removal.

Troubled Wang Laboratories Inc., which has been criticized for having too limited a product line, said it would expand its line of computer equipment that uses popular industrywide standards. Analysts said Wednesday's move marks an important departure for Wang, which has suffered recent losses and has slashed its work force. The move follows a recent trend in which computer companies have been making equipment that is compatible with that of other manufacturers.

The stock market drifted through a trendless session Wednesday, registering no strong reaction to the U.S. military action in Panama. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 7.68 to 2,687.93. The dollar finished mostly lower in the United States after ending mixed overseas in what dealers called a muted response to the events in Panama. Treasury bill yields tumbled and bond prices were narrowly mixed after the Federal Reserve appeared to signal an easing of monetary policy. Orange juice futures prices rose; sugar futures fell; coffee futures gained; precious metals advanced; energy futures were mixed; grains and soybeans fell; and livestock and meat futures retreated.
